Upon [inspection of the contract creation][tenderly-trace], the input appears in clear:

```json
{
  "[OPCODE]": "CREATE",
  "from": {
    "address": "0xb7257d8ba61bd1b3fb7249dcd9330a023a5f3670",
    "balance": "0"
  },
  "to": {
    "address": "0x1f8557ab4d848665cf09b108ca4d5384c3bd3a3e",
    "balance": "0"
  },
  "value": "0",
  "[INPUT]": "",
  "[OUTPUT]": "",
  "gas": {
    "gas_left": 426686,
    "gas_used": 85460,
    "total_gas_used": 73314
  }
}
```

The `INPUT` field has the constructor argument appended to the bytecode of the contract.
For example, we can decode the last 8 bytes:

```js
// 'sword :)'
web3.utils.hexToAscii('0x73776f7264203a29')
```

We're definitely on the right track!
Taking a longer chunk will give us the entire password:

```js
// 'C\x00\b\f\x003A very strong secret password :)'
web3.utils.hexToAscii('0x4300080c0033412076657279207374726f6e67207365637265742070617373776f7264203a29')
```

Now we can use these 32 bytes to unlock the vault:

```js
password = '0x412076657279207374726f6e67207365637265742070617373776f7264203a29';
contract.unlock(password)
await contract.locked()// false
```

Another possibility is to read the private storage on the blockchain:

```js
// 0x412076657279207374726f6e67207365637265742070617373776f7264203a29
await web3.eth.getStorageAt(contract.address, 1, (err,res)=>{console.log(res)});
```

[tenderly-trace]: https://dashboard.tenderly.co/tx/sepolia/0x27ac0e6126f7c9d2426570f37c69e37485a3f04fd49f96dccc70a0fda5cf1aa2?trace=0.0.0
